subject: Accounting
topics: Welcome test and cash book-three column cash book working exercise on three column cash books

learningObjectives.value: By the end of the lesson, students should be able to: I] post transactions into three column cash book  balance up the three column cash book

learningActivities.value: -students as a class post entries to the three column cash book -students as a class balance up the three column cash book

embeddedCoreSkills.value: -Critical thinking and problem solving -Collaboration and Communication Digital literacy -leadership and personal development

learningResources.value: Audio-Visual Resources Recall /improvised cash book Display of work on the topics  Web resources

subject: Accounting
topics: Cash book three column cash book working exercise

learningObjectives.value: By the end of the lesson, students should be able to: post complex transactions into three column cash book balance up the three column cash book

learningActivities.value: -students in small groups, solve questions on three column cash book -students as a class visit the site for the meaning of petty cash book and terms used in petty cash book

embeddedCoreSkills.value: -Critical thinking and problem solving -Collaboration and Communication Digital literacy -leadership and personal development

learningResources.value: Audio-visual Resources Real/improved cash book Display of work on the topics  Web Resources

subject: Accounting
topics: Petty cash book Meaning -terminologies Imprest system Reimbursement and working exercises

learningObjectives.value: By the end of the lesson, students should be able to: I] regulate the meaning of petty cash book and terminologies associated with petty cash book  explain the concept of imprest system  demonstrate the concept of reimbursement Iv] prepare a typical petty cash book

learningActivities.value: -class presentation on the process of imprest system -students as a class, prepare petty cash book -student as individual post entries to the petty cash book and calculate how much float is given

embeddedCoreSkills.value: -Critical thinking and problem solving -Digital literacy -Leadership and personal development

learningResources.value: Audio-visual Resources Poster on the format of petty cash book Picture of a petty cashier, real or improved petty voucher Reimbursement demonstrated in practical term  Web Resources

subject: Accounting
topics: Posting subsidiary books into ledges cash book, sales day book, purchases day book, return inwards and return outwards

learningObjectives.value: By the end of the lesson, students should be able to: I] transfer entries in subsidiary books to ledgers

learningActivities.value: Students in small groups post entries from subsidiary books to ledgers

embeddedCoreSkills.value: Critical thinking and problem solving -Collaboration and Communication Digital literacy -leadership and

subject: Accounting
topics: Trial balance Meaning , uses Rules for extraction, extraction of trial balance Working exercises

learningObjectives.value: By the end of the lesson, students should be able to: I] explain the meaning of trial balance  discuss the rules guiding the extraction of trial balance  extract a trial balance

learningActivities.value: -students in  pairs to I] define trial balance Ii] discuss the rules for extracting trial balance -students as a class prepare trial balance -students to visit the link below to study on accounting concepts and conventions

embeddedCoreSkills.value: -critical  thinking and problem solving  -digital literacy Leadership and personal development

subject: Accounting
topics: Accounting concepts and conventions Meaning and types of accounting Concepts Meaning and types of accounting convention

learningObjectives.value: By the end of the lesson, students should be able to: I] write out accounting concepts and conventions Ii] distinguish between accounting concepts and conventions Iii] justify the need for accounting concepts  and conventions

learningActivities.value: Students as a class explain accounting concepts  and conventions and the types -students in small groups draw up the differences between accounting concepts and conventions -students in pairs explain the reasons for accounting concepts and conventions

embeddedCoreSkills.value: Critical thinking and problem solving -leadership and personal development

subject: Accounting
topics: Final accounts of a sole trader -trading profit or loss account –meaning , reasons, format

subject: Accounting
topics: Final accounts of a sole trader -trading profit or loss account –meaning , reasons, format

learningObjectives.value: By the end of the lesson, students should be able to: I] define trading profit or loss account Ii] construct a trading profit or loss account from an illustration Iii] interpret the end result in trading , profit or loss account

learningActivities.value: -students in pairs define trading profit or loss account -students as a class, prepare trading , profit or loss account -students in small groups interpret the end result in the trading , profit or loss account prepared

embeddedCoreSkills.value: Critical thinking and problem solving -Collaboration and Communication Digital literacy -leadership and personal development

subject: Accounting
topics: Balance sheet Meaning and format Assets and liabilities Working exercises on final accounts

learningObjectives.value: By the end of the lesson, students should be able to I] describe balance sheet in your own words Ii] state the purposes of balance sheet Iii] explain with adequate examples assets and liabilities

learningActivities.value: -students in pairs give the meaning of balance sheet Students as a class , state the purposes of balance sheet -students in small groups, explain with examples. Assets and liabilities and prepare a balance sheet

embeddedCoreSkills.value: Critical thinking and problem solving -Collaboration and Communication Digital literacy -leadership and personal development

subject: Accounting
topics: Simple accounting ratio-meaning, types and working exercise

learningObjectives.value: Iv] draw out a typical balance sheet

By the end of the lesson, students should be able to: I] appraise the need for adjustment to final account Ii] compare and contrast between types of reserves Iii] discriminate between provisions  and reserves

learningActivities.value: -students as a class prepare balance sheet

-students as a class explain adjustment and give reasons for adjustments -students in small groups compare the types of reserves -students in pairs draw up the differences between provisions and reserves

embeddedCoreSkills.value: -critical thinking and problem solving -Digital literacy -leadership  and personal development
